'''ByteDance Ltd.''' ({{zh|p=Zìjié Tiàodòng|c=字节跳动}}) is a Chinese internet technology company headquartered in [[Beijing]] and incorporated in the [[Cayman Islands]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last1=Yang |first1=Yingzhi |last2=Goh |first2=Brenda |date=2021-08-17 |title=Beijing took stake and board seat in key ByteDance domestic entity this year |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/china/beijing-owns-stakes-bytedance-weibo-domestic-entities-records-show-2021-08-17/ |access-date=2022-07-27}}</ref>

Founded by [[Zhang Yiming]], Liang Rubo and a team of others in 2012, ByteDance developed the [[Online video platform|video-sharing]] [[social networking service]]s and [[Mobile app|apps]] [[TikTok|TikTok and Chinese-specific counterpart Douyin]]. The company is also the developer of the news platform [[Toutiao]]. {{As of|June 2021|post=,}} ByteDance hosts 1.9 billion monthly active users across all of its platforms.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lin |first=Liza |date=17 June 2021 |title=TikTok Owner ByteDance's Annual Revenue Jumps to $34.3 Billion |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/tiktok-owner-bytedances-annual-revenue-jumps-to-34-3-billion-11623903622 |url-status=live |url-access=subscription |access-date=29 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210930183636/https://www.wsj.com/articles/tiktok-owner-bytedances-annual-revenue-jumps-to-34-3-billion-11623903622 |archive-date=30 September 2021}}</ref>{{Update inline|date=October 2022}}

ByteDance has attracted legislative and media attention in several countries over security, surveillance, and [[Chinese censorship abroad|censorship]] concerns.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite news |last=Baker-White |first=Emily |date=April 21, 2023 |title=Security Failures At TikTok's Virginia Data Centers: Unescorted Visitors, Mystery Flash Drives And Illicit Crypto Mining |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2023/04/21/security-failures-tiktok-virginia-data-centers-unescorted-visitors-flash-drives/ |access-date=2023-04-30 |website=[[Forbes]] |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Milmo |first=Dan |date=2022-11-08 |title=TikTok's ties to China: why concerns over your data are here to stay |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/nov/07/tiktoks-china-bytedance-data-concerns |access-date=2022-12-03 |website=[[The Guardian]] |language=en}}</ref>

== History ==
In 2009, [[software engineering|software engineer]] and entrepreneur [[Zhang Yiming]] collaborated with his friend Liang Rubo to co-found 99fang.com, a real estate search engine.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lu |first=Shen |date=20 May 2021 |title=New ByteDance CEO Liang Rubo getting a warm welcome, leaked posts show |work=Protocol |publisher=[[Politico]] |url=https://www.protocol.com/china/bytedance-ceo-liang-rubo |url-status=live |access-date=23 June 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210619102550/https://www.protocol.com/china/bytedance-ceo-liang-rubo |archive-date=19 June 2021}}</ref> In early 2012, the pair rented an apartment in [[Zhongguancun]] and, along with several other 99fang employees, began developing an app that would use [[big data]] algorithms to classify news according to users' preferences, which would later become [[Toutiao]].<ref name="JWu">{{cite news |last=Wu |first=Julianna |date=28 May 2021 |title=Meet Liang Rubo, the 'executor' and former roommate of Zhang Yiming, who's ready to take over at ByteDance |work=KrASIA |url=https://kr-asia.com/liang-rubo-the-executor-and-former-roommate-of-zhang-yiming-ready-to-take-over-as-ceo-at-bytedance |url-status=live |access-date=23 June 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210624034049/https://kr-asia.com/liang-rubo-the-executor-and-former-roommate-of-zhang-yiming-ready-to-take-over-as-ceo-at-bytedance |archive-date=24 June 2021}}</ref> That March, Yiming and Liang founded ByteDance.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ting |first=Deanna |date=30 October 2019 |title=Everything you need to know about ByteDance, the company behind TikTok |work=[[Digiday]] |url=https://digiday.com/media/everything-you-need-to-know-about-bytedance-the-company-behind-tiktok/ |url-status=live |access-date=23 June 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200413084015/https://digiday.com/media/everything-you-need-to-know-about-bytedance-the-company-behind-tiktok/ |archive-date=13 April 2020}}</ref>

=== Launch of first apps ===
In March 2012, ByteDance launched its first app, called ''Neihan Duanzi'' ({{lang|zh|内涵段子}}, lit. "profound [[running gag|gag]]s"). This allowed users to circulate jokes, memes, and humorous videos. Before being forced by the [[Government of China|Chinese government]] to shut down in 2018, ''Neihan Duanzi'' had over 200 million users.<ref>{{Cite news |title=宁静上《冒犯家族》遭"吐槽" 内涵段子app用户的神评论太犀利了 |url=http://tech.ifeng.com/a/20171128/44780603_0.shtml |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190618031413/http://tech.ifeng.com/a/20171128/44780603_0.shtml |archive-date=18 June 2019 |access-date=18 June 2019 |work=[[Phoenix TV]] |language=zh}}</ref>

In August 2012, ByteDance launched the first version of news and content platform Toutiao (头条, lit. "[[headline]]s"), which would become their core product.<ref name="Bischoff">{{Cite news |last=Bischoff |first=Paul |date=3 June 2014 |title=The simple news reader app that's taking China by storm just netted $100 million funding from Sequoia Capital |work=[[Tech in Asia]] |url=https://www.techinasia.com/simple-news-reader-app-china-storm-netted-100-million-funding-sequoia-capital |url-status=live |access-date=12 January 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180513151939/https://www.techinasia.com/simple-news-reader-app-china-storm-netted-100-million-funding-sequoia-capital |archive-date=13 May 2018}}</ref>

In January 2013, in an attempt for [[commercialism]] and [[nationalism]], a four-part plan for the future was presented to executives. Part four of the plan was to build an English version of Toutiao to gain users in English-speaking countries. At the time, there was an app race for video views and the attention of phone users.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Stokel-Walker |first=Chris |title=TikTok Boom: China's Dynamite App and the Superpower Race for Social Media |date=2023-01-24 |publisher=Sourcebooks, Inc. |isbn=978-1-7282-8345-6 |language=en}}</ref>

=== Expansion ===
In March 2016, ByteDance established its research arm, called the ByteDance AI Lab. It is headed by Wei-Ying Ma, the former assistant managing director of Microsoft Research Asia.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Feng |first=Emily |date=9 May 2017 |title=Toutiao touts AI for individual news in vast China market |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/04b55fdc-28b7-11e7-9ec8-168383da43b7 |url-status=live |url-access=subscription |access-date=12 November 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190922190843/https://www.ft.com/content/04b55fdc-28b7-11e7-9ec8-168383da43b7 |archive-date=22 September 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Knight |first=Will |date=26 January 2017 |title=This Chinese media giant is using machine learning to go after Facebook's lunch |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/603351/the-insanely-popular-chinese-news-app-that-youve-never-heard-of/?set=603509 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200823225452/https://www.technologyreview.com/2017/01/26/154363/the-insanely-popular-chinese-news-app-that-youve-never-heard-of/ |archive-date=23 August 2020 |access-date=12 January 2018 |work=[[MIT Technology Review]]}}</ref>

From late 2016 until 2017, ByteDance made a number of acquisitions and new product launches. In December 2016, it invested in the Indonesian news recommendation platform BABE.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Toutiao Pushes Short Video Business Globalization With USD1 Billion Musical.ly Takeover |work=Yicai Global |publisher=[[Shanghai Media Group]] |url=https://www.yicaiglobal.com/news/toutiao-pushes-short-video-business-globalization-usd1-billion-musically-takeover |url-status=live |access-date=2018-01-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507153659/https://www.yicaiglobal.com/news/toutiao-pushes-short-video-business-globalization-usd1-billion-musically-takeover |archive-date=2018-05-07}}</ref> Two months later, in February 2017, it acquired Flipagram, which was later merged with Musical.ly into TikTok upon the latter's acquisition in November 2017. Other notable acquisitions include the UGC short video platform Hypstar (Vigo Video) in July 2017,<ref>{{Cite news|script-title=zh:文化"走出去"的方式有很多 短视频应用出海成小潮流|trans-title=There are many ways to 'go global' for culture, short video applications are becoming a trend|url=http://new.qq.com/omn/20171205A0XBIO.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200823225455/https://new.qq.com/omn/20171205/20171205A0XBIO.html|archive-date=23 August 2020|access-date=12 January 2018|work=New.QQ.com}}</ref> and News Republic from [[Cheetah Mobile]] in November 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Jing |first=Meng |date=10 November 2017 |title=China's Toutiao buys teen-favourite video creation app Musical.ly |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |url=https://www.scmp.com/tech/start-ups/article/2119369/chinas-toutiao-buys-teens-social-video-app-musically-latest-expansion |url-status=live |access-date=14 November 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191114162717/https://www.scmp.com/tech/start-ups/article/2119369/chinas-toutiao-buys-teens-social-video-app-musically-latest-expansion |archive-date=14 November 2019}}</ref>

In December 2018, ByteDance sued Chinese technology news site Huxiu for defamation after Huxiu reported that ByteDance's Indian-language news app Helo was propagating [[fake news]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Liao |first=Rita |date=2018-12-19 |title=TikTok parent ByteDance sues Chinese news site that exposed fake news problem |url=http://techcrunch.com/2018/12/19/tiktok-parent-bytedance-sues-chinese-news-site-that-exposed-fake-news-problem/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190302090519/https://techcrunch.com/2018/12/19/tiktok-parent-bytedance-sues-chinese-news-site-that-exposed-fake-news-problem/ |archive-date=2 March 2019 |access-date=1 March 2019 |work=[[TechCrunch]]}}</ref>

In March 2021, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that ByteDance was part of a group of Chinese companies that aimed to deploy technology to circumvent [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s privacy policies.<ref>{{Cite news |date=16 March 2021 |title=China's tech giants test way around Apple's new privacy rules |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/520ccdae-202f-45f9-a516-5cbe08361c34 |url-status=live |url-access=subscription |access-date=19 March 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210318162325/https://www.ft.com/content/520ccdae-202f-45f9-a516-5cbe08361c34 |archive-date=18 March 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Gurman|first=Mark|date=2021-03-19|title=Apple Warns Against Unauthorized Tracking After China Workaround|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-19/apple-warns-against-unauthorized-tracking-after-china-workaround|url-status=live|access-date=19 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210319005729/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-19/apple-warns-against-unauthorized-tracking-after-china-workaround|archive-date=19 March 2021}}</ref>

In April 2021, ByteDance announced that it had created a new division called BytePlus to distribute the software framework underlying TikTok, so that others may launch similar apps.<ref>{{Cite news |date=29 April 2021 |title=ByteDance's New BytePlus Division Is Selling TikTok's Underlying Tech |work=[[Business Insider]] |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/bytedances-new-byteplus-division-selling-tiktoks-underlying-tech-2021-4 |url-status=live |access-date=29 April 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210429071313/https://www.businessinsider.com/bytedances-new-byteplus-division-selling-tiktoks-underlying-tech-2021-4 |archive-date=29 April 2021}}</ref>

In August 2021, ByteDance acquired Pico, an Oculus-like [[virtual reality]] startup.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Kharpal |first=Arjun |date=2021-08-30 |title=TikTok owner ByteDance takes first step into virtual reality with latest acquisition |language=en |website=[[CNBC]] |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/30/tiktok-owner-bytedance-acquires-pico-and-takes-first-step-into-virtual-reality.html |url-status=live |access-date=2022-04-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220408061927/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/30/tiktok-owner-bytedance-acquires-pico-and-takes-first-step-into-virtual-reality.html |archive-date=8 April 2022}}</ref>

In June 2022, the ''Financial Times'' reported on a culture clash at ByteDance's London office that has led to a staff exodus.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-06-08 |title=TikTok Shop's troubled UK expansion: staff exodus and culture clash |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/dc1aba86-2055-4521-8f0c-1f026c7f6864 |url-access=subscription |access-date=2023-01-03}}</ref>

In March 2023, [[The Wall Street Journal|''The'' ''Wall Street Journal'']] reported that former employees allege that the company engages in a practice called "horse racing," in which several teams are assigned to build the same product.<ref name=":12" /> When one version is deemed to perform better, the team designing the better version is provided with more support.<ref name=":12" />

In April 2023, ByteDance filed a trademark for a book publisher called 8th Note Press.<ref name=":14">{{Cite news |last1=Harris |first1=Elizabeth A. |last2=Alter |first2=Alexandra |date=2023-07-01 |title=TikTok Sells A Lot of Books. Now, Its Owner Wants to Publish Them, Too. |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/01/books/tiktok-book-publishing-bytedance.html |access-date=2023-07-02 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

In December 2023, [[The Verge]] reported that ByteDance used OpenAI's [[API]] for its own [[generative AI]] projects. Afterwards, [[OpenAI]] announced that while usage by ByteDance was minimal, its account has been suspended pending further investigation whether any [[terms of service]] were violated. ByteDance stated that it had been licensed for using the API outside the Chinese market, its own chatbot is available only within China, and [[ChatGPT]]-generated data have been deleted from ByteDance's training data since the middle of 2023. Scraping existing AI models is a common shortcut for smaller companies but considered unusual for the likes of ByteDance.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Heath |first1=Alex |title=ByteDance is secretly using OpenAI's tech to build a competitor |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/12/15/24003151/bytedance-china-openai-microsoft-competitor-llm |work=The Verge |date=15 December 2023 |language=en}}</ref>

== Corporate affairs ==
=== Funding and ownership ===
ByteDance is financially backed by [[Jeff Yass]]' [[Susquehanna International Group]], [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts]], [[SoftBank Group]], [[Sequoia Capital]], [[General Atlantic]], and [[Hillhouse Capital Group]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Roumeliotis |first=Greg |date=1 November 2019 |title=U.S. opens national security investigation into TikTok - sources |work=[[Reuters]] |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tiktok-cfius-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-opens-national-security-investigation-into-tiktok-sources-idUSKBN1XB4IL |url-status=live |access-date=2 November 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191102162126/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tiktok-cfius-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-opens-national-security-investigation-into-tiktok-sources-idUSKBN1XB4IL |archive-date=2 November 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last1=McKinnon |first1=John D. |last2=Woo |first2=Stu |date=2023-09-20 |title=The Billionaire Keeping TikTok on Phones in the U.S. |url=https://www.wsj.com/politics/policy/jeff-yass-tiktok-bytedance-ban-congress-15a41ec4 |url-access=subscription |access-date=2023-09-20 |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |language=en-US}}</ref>  {{As of|2021|03}}, it was estimated to be valued at $250 billion in private trades.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Yilun Chen |first1=Lulu |last2=Liu |first2=Coco |last3=Huang |first3=Zheping |date=30 March 2021 |title=ByteDance Valued at $250 Billion in Private Trades |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-30/bytedance-is-said-valued-at-250-billion-in-private-trades |url-status=live |access-date=31 March 2021 |archive-date=30 March 2021 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20210330194043/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-30/bytedance-is-said-valued-at-250-billion-in-private-trades}}</ref>{{Update inline|date=March 2023}}

On 19 May 2020, ByteDance and Disney released an announcement that Kevin Mayer, head of Disney's streaming business, would join ByteDance. From June 2020 to his resignation 26 August 2020, Mayer served as the CEO of TikTok and the COO of ByteDance, reporting directly to the company CEO Zhang Yiming.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Isaac |first=Mike |date=28 August 2020 |title=TikTok Chief Executive Kevin Mayer Resigns |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/27/technology/tiktok-kevin-mayer-resign.html |url-status=live |access-date=1 October 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200928190954/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/27/technology/tiktok-kevin-mayer-resign.html |archive-date=28 September 2020 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Leskin |first=Paige |title=TikTok's CEO left 3 months into the job after getting boxed out by ByteDance during TikTok's biggest moment of crisis |work=[[Business Insider]] |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-ceo-kevin-mayer-resigns-control-acquisition-bytedance-zhang-yiming-2020-8 |url-status=live |access-date=1 October 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200928162920/https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-ceo-kevin-mayer-resigns-control-acquisition-bytedance-zhang-yiming-2020-8 |archive-date=28 September 2020}}</ref> In 2021, Shou Zi Chew, former CFO of [[Xiaomi]], took over as TikTok CEO.<ref>{{cite news |last=Byford |first=Sam |date=20 May 2021 |title=Founder of TikTok owner ByteDance resigns as CEO |work=[[The Verge]] |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/20/22445212/tiktok-bytedance-ceo-zhang-yiming-steps-down |url-status=live |access-date=20 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210520062713/https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/20/22445212/tiktok-bytedance-ceo-zhang-yiming-steps-down |archive-date=20 May 2021}}</ref>

{{main|Toutiao}}
Toutiao ({{Lang-zh|s=今日头条|p=Jīnrì Tóutiáo}}), launched in August 2012,<ref name="Bischoff" /> started out as a news [[recommendation engine]] and gradually evolved into a platform delivering content in various formats, such as texts, images, question-and-answer posts, [[microblogs]], and videos.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.theinformation.com/articles/how-a-news-startup-caught-chinas-tencent-by-surprise |title=How a News Startup Caught China's Tencent by Surprise |last=Osawa |first=Juro |date=19 July 2017 |work=The Information |access-date=23 March 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180513011208/https://www.theinformation.com/articles/how-a-news-startup-caught-chinas-tencent-by-surprise |archive-date=13 May 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-24/in-battle-for-talent-one-startup-founder-tries-unlimited-pay |title=This Startup Is Luring Top Talent with $3 Million Pay Packages |date=24 September 2017 |work=Bloomberg |access-date=23 March 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180308184936/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-24/in-battle-for-talent-one-startup-founder-tries-unlimited-pay |archive-date=8 March 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref>

In January 2014, the company created the "Toutiaohao" ({{lang|zh|头条号}}) platform to attract more content creators. Later in the year, it added video capabilities. In November 2022, during the [[2022 COVID-19 protests in China]], the CAC directed ByteDance to intensify its censorship of the protests.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Lin |first=Liza |date=2022-12-01 |title=WSJ News Exclusive {{!}} China Clamps Down on Internet as It Seeks to Stamp Out Covid Protests |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-clamps-down-on-internet-as-it-seeks-to-stamp-out-covid-protests-11669905228 |url-access=subscription |access-date=2023-07-17 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

In November 2023, ''Forbes'' reported that ByteDance's internal workplace tool called Feishu, which contains "product network security, data security, personal information, and daily operations," was accessed by the CAC and other Chinese government authorities in the run-up to the [[20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party]].<ref name=":15">{{Cite news |last=Baker-White |first=Emily |date=November 1, 2023 |title=A Platform Storing TikTok Corporate Secrets Was Inspected By The Chinese Government |work=[[Forbes]] |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2023/11/01/a-platform-storing-tiktok-corporate-secrets-was-inspected-by-the-chinese-government/?sh=32d502e23b27 |access-date=December 19, 2023}}</ref>

=== India ===
{{See also|Censorship of TikTok}}
Citing national security issues the [[Indian Government]] banned CapCut and TikTok along with 58 other Chinese apps on 29 June 2020.<ref>{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Manish|date=29 June 2020|title=India bans TikTok, dozens of other Chinese apps|work=[[TechCrunch]]|url=https://techcrunch.com/2020/06/29/india-bans-tiktok-dozens-of-other-chinese-apps/|url-status=live|access-date=3 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200802205737/https://techcrunch.com/2020/06/29/india-bans-tiktok-dozens-of-other-chinese-apps/|archive-date=2 August 2020}}</ref> The ban was made permanent in January 2021.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Singh|first=Kanishka|date=25 January 2021|title=India to impose permanent ban on 59 Chinese apps, including TikTok - Indian media|work=[[Reuters]]|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-india-china-apps-idUSKBN29U2G6|url-status=live|access-date=25 January 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210126024007/https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-india-china-apps-idUSKBN29U2G6|archive-date=26 January 2021}}</ref><ref name=":10" /> In March 2021, the Indian government froze ByteDance's bank accounts in the country for alleged tax evasion, which ByteDance disputed.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Kalra |first1=Aditya |last2=Roy |first2=Abhirup |date=30 March 2021 |title=India blocks bank accounts of China's ByteDance, company mounts challenge |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bytedance-india-banks-exclusive-idUSKBN2BM20F |url-status=live |access-date=31 March 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210330231748/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bytedance-india-banks-exclusive-idUSKBN2BM20F |archive-date=30 March 2021}}</ref>

=== Taiwan ===
In December 2022, Taiwan's [[Mainland Affairs Council]] announced an investigation into ByteDance on suspicion of operating an illegal subsidiary in the country.<ref>{{Cite news |last= |date=2022-12-19 |title=Taiwan probes TikTok for suspected illegal operations |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/taiwan-probes-tiktok-suspected-illegal-operations-2022-12-19/ |access-date=2022-12-19}}</ref> The company reportedly registered "Tiktoktaiwan Co Ltd" in March, which changed its name to "ByteDance Taiwan" in November.<ref>{{Cite news |date=20 December 2022 |title=Bills on TikTok disinformation mulled |work=[[Taipei Times]] |url=https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2022/12/20/2003791030 |access-date=20 December 2022}}</ref>

==== FBI investigation ====
In March 2023, the [[United States Department of Justice]] and the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] opened an investigation into ByteDance over its alleged surveillance of journalists.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news |last=Baker-White |first=Emily |date=March 16, 2023 |title=The FBI And DOJ Are Investigating ByteDance's Use Of TikTok To Spy On Journalists |language=en |website=[[Forbes]] |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2023/03/16/fbi-doj-investigating-bytedance-tiktok-surveillance-journalists/ |access-date=2023-03-17}}</ref> The investigation was launched following a 2022 ''[[BuzzFeed News]]'' report. In response, ByteDance stated that certain employees, since terminated, had misused their authority to [[TikTok#Journalist spying scandal|surveil journalists]] working for ''BuzzFeed'' and the ''Financial Times'' in order to find leaks to the press.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Duffy |first=Clare |date=2022-12-22 |title=TikTok confirms that journalists' data was accessed by employees of its parent company |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/12/22/tech/tiktok-bytedance-journalist-data/index.html |access-date=2022-12-23 |website=[[CNN]] |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author1=Kleinman |first=Zoe |date=5 May 2023 |title=TikTok tracked UK journalist via her cat's account |publisher=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-65126056 |access-date=7 June 2023}}</ref> The company stated that it would cooperate with governmental investigations and continue its own internal review.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Gurman |first=Sadie |date=March 17, 2023 |title=Justice Department Probes TikTok's Tracking of U.S. Journalists |language=en-US |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/justice-department-probes-tiktoks-tracking-of-u-s-journalists-d7e47665 |url-access=subscription |access-date=2023-03-22}}</ref> In December 2023, all members of the [[United States House Select Committee on Strategic Competition between the United States and the Chinese Communist Party]] requested a confidential briefing with the FBI on the investigation.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Baker-White |first=Emily |date=December 7, 2023 |title=Congress Wants Answers About The FBI And DOJ's TikTok Investigation |work=[[Forbes]] |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2023/12/07/congress-wants-answers-about-fbi-doj-tiktok-investigation/?sh=3e8520d378df |access-date=December 8, 2023}}</ref>

==== State level ====
In May 2023, Montana became the first state to ban TikTok.<ref name=":16">{{Cite news |last=Archie |first=Ayana |date=May 18, 2023 |title=Montana becomes the first state to ban TikTok |url=https://www.npr.org/2023/05/18/1176805559/montana-tiktok-ban |access-date=December 20, 2023 |website=[[NPR]]}}</ref> Under its Senate Bill 419, effective January 1, 2024, platforms hosting the TikTok app in their marketplaces, including the Google Play Store and Apple App Store, would face daily fines of up to $10,000 for non-compliance.<ref name=":16" /> In November 2023, a federal judge issued a preliminary ruling and blocked the Montana law, stating the ban "oversteps state power" and "likely violates the First Amendment."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Allyn |first=Bobby |date=November 30, 2023 |title=Federal judge blocks Montana's TikTok ban before it takes effect |url=https://www.npr.org/2023/11/30/1205735647/montana-tiktok-ban-blocked-state |access-date=December 20, 2023 |website=[[NPR]]}}</ref>
